instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.820-3539: What is 820-3539? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message: I have a macbook pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (13" Mid-2014) with board number <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that no longer powers on. When only fan and DC-in board/power cable is plugged into motherboard, I get fan spin that gradually accelerates as well as a green-then-orange light on charging cable. When the macbook is fully assembled, I do not get any lights on the charging cable or signs of life from computer. The main power rail is present, any ideas on where to look? Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message: History? Liquid? Is CPU Vcore present on L7310?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message: Does not appear to be any liquid damage (although plenty of dust/hairs everywhere). Laptop has supposedly been through regular wear for a couple years. It died and no longer powers on or does anything except when I have motherboard out of computer. Will check for Vcore on L7310  and let you know what I find

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message: CPU VCore was present at L7310 at (1.7V). On the schematic it is listed as <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> which blends with PH2 to make <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>. Both phases are present and at proper voltages. CPU is getting warm when board is out and adapter is plugged in. Also, after further testing, I have realized that P3v3S0 is missing from all points I tested on the board. Found the <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> switch (<CHIP>U8030</CHIP>) and found that the <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>  signal is missing. It is my understanding that this switch is what sends the signal to CPU to activate S0 (on) state. Since the enable signal for this switch is missing, then the chip would never tell computer to actually switch to on state. Am I understanding this correctly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> must be present for CPU Vcore to be there. Double check that Vcore is present and <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is really missing, it should not be happening.
Also the enable for <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> comes straight from all the other S0 enables, so check voltage on both sides of <RESISTOR>R8186</RESISTOR>.

Don't use comments, use reply.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message:
You were right dukefawks. I rechecked my measurements and found that CPUVcore is present as well as the 3.3v enable signal for <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>. I took a bunch of measurements and observed operation. With board installed into computer, I get a green/orange light, but no fan spin and no other signs of life. When the board is external with only fan and DV cord plugged in, I get green/orange light as well as fan spin and a warm CPU. Main power rails are active and I took some measurements and thought I would record some of the more important ones here to help with troubleshooting:

Vcore present:
3v3 enable at <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> present
All 5V rails present for S5-S0 states
5VS5 present at <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> present at pin 1 of <CHIP>U1420</CHIP>
3V present at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R8162</RESISTOR>
Also verified that all S3 rails for each state are present as well

For the most part it seems as if the power rails are active and present. Any more ideas on where I should check? Heck it could even be hardware at this point but I am pretty sure I ruled that out already.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message: Was able to determine that it was the I/O board attached that was shorting out the computer. As soon as the connector is plugged into J9500, I only get orange light and no fan spin. With everything plugged in besides J9500, the entire computer powers on and works fine. Why do you think this is happening? The board number for the I/O board is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3539</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. The daughter board looks very healthy and devoid of corrosion/burnt areas.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message: No use in diagnosing an IO board, first try a known good one including cable. The board should work fine without it connected, so test that too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message: The computer works great without the cable plugged in, although the trackapad is incredibly laggy at the Admin sign-in screen but works fine once signed in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power Issue
threads.message: That is normal because it is missing a few thermal sensors. Get another IO board and cable and see if that fixes it.
